biography.headline: Applied ML and Engineering Solutions
summary: Leonardo Matone is a PhD student and AI Innovation Fellow in the Computer Science department of Tulane University, currently working under Dr. Nicholas Mattei.

He works full time at Tulane in applied machine learning, contributing to interdisciplinary research and innovation initiatives. His interests include natural language processing, public policy data science, and political science.

Outside of applied ML, Leonardo researches computational social choice, focusing on novel probabilistic social choice functions, and he earned dual bachelor's degrees in Computer Science and Political Science from Hunter College as a Thomas Hunter Scholar.

blogPosts.title: Using PyTorch on Apple Sillicon
blogPosts.snippet: TIL that Torch has *Metal* support. It's insane
blogPosts.subtitle: Notes from DeepVoting
content:
mps device enables high-performance training on GPU for MacOS devices with Metal programming framework. It introduces a new device to map Machine Learning computational graphs and primitives on highly efficient Metal Performance Shaders Graph framework and tuned kernels provided by Metal Performance Shaders framework respectively. 
 The new MPS backend extends the PyTorch ecosystem and provides existing scripts capabilities to setup and run operations on GPU. 
 https://docs.pytorch.org/docs/stable/notes/mps.html

blogPosts.title: Vibe Coding Web as a Backend Developer
blogPosts.snippet: Tools like Codex enable crazy cross-stack work for developers with limited experience but good domain knowledge
blogPosts.subtitle: Personal Development
content:
My expertise is in backend development, with some data science and analysis mixed in. I'm studying and honing my AI/ML toolkit at Tulane, and FE has never been for me. Yet I hope you'll agree that this website is absolutely excellent, despite being built by yours truly. Building this site was not easy; this is mainly because I have next to no real experience with web development outside of some shoddy frontend views of projects I've built in the past. I vibe-coded the hell out of this. It's interesting because I've seen students and colleagues talking and implementing via 'vibe' in the past, and it's such an interesting dilemma to me. Part of me is certainly positive about this new progression in the field, as is Nvidia's CEO, but another part of me sees these new powers being used for evil, or at least, ignorance. Vibe coding does eliminate the hours and even years of domain knowledge needed to build things, but the act of building things still takes hours and hours of work. 
While I have used LLM tools in the past, this was my first proper 'vibe-code.' JavaScript eludes me, so I came into this with my programming knowledge, a few general structure ideas, and a dream. Here are my takeaways. 
Vibe coding sucks. It's a joke- and while it enabled me to finish this project, I learned a significant amount about REACT in order to wrap it up. I would often spend +2 hours working on a feature only for one wrong prompt to nuke all of my progress, including my json storing all of my data,
